awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research on Security of Mobile Devices and Wireless Networks at NYIT
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award funds the renewal of an outstanding REU site at New York Institute of Technology.   The site will recruit undergraduates from across the nation to participate in research related to securing mobile devices such as smart phones and wireless networks.  Securing mobile devices and networks is an area of current interest that is well-suited to undergraduate research productivity.   The students will address the challenges of securing mobile devices and wireless networks by creating new biometrics for seamless and secure user authentication on mobile devices, developing power-efficient, privacy-preserving cryptographic protocols for secure wireless communications, detecting malware and identifying attacks of mobile devices to protect data integrity and privacy, and securing medical devices and data. This site should help develop a group of computing professionals who can design the systems of the future that impact society and enhance our quality of life. The REU experience provides students with the foundations and inspiration to pursue computing careers and research in areas that are rapidly evolving and are of importance to the nation.   

The project is led by a team of researchers offering state-of-the-art facilities and professional mentors to guide undergraduates in explorations of problems related to mobile security. Students will learn how to use current tools and techniques to solve those problems that have direct impact on people.  The team will use proven strategies to recruit undergraduate students from groups traditionally under-represented in computer science.   The students will participate in research and professional development activities all designed to achieve the goals of retaining and graduating undergraduate students in computer science and engineering, and increasing recruitment of students into graduate programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site's objective is to attract talented and motivated undergraduate students, with a particular emphasis on women and minority undergraduate students, from diverse backgrounds to conduct meaningful research with the faculty of the College of Engineering and Computing Sciences (CoECS) at NYIT.

The major goals of the REU Site are: (1) Introducing security research on mobile devices and wireless networks to undergraduate students and preparing them for graduate studies. (2) Increasing the number of women and students from underrepresented groups who engage in security research and provide support for them to become security researchers. (3) Providing research opportunities in high-demand cyber and mobile security areas to those who would otherwise have had no access to research facilities. (4) Increasing awareness of and approaches to challenging problems in the security of mobile devices and networks.

The team completed the project with strong support from the NYIT College of Engineering and Computing Sciences, Office of Sponsored Programs and Research, Office of Strategic Communications and External Affairs, Admissions Office, and Financial Aid Office. The team advertised nationally through the NSF REU program website and professional mailing lists. Team members shared the program recruitment announcements with community colleges, Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), Spanish-Serving Institutions (HSIs), and Women's Colleges. Additionally, the help of various societies and student clubs, which include the Society of Women Engineers (SWE) and the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE), are mobilized in the recruitment efforts. The project mentors attended SWE and NSBE conferences and promoted the program.

Between 2019 and 2022, the site attracted a diverse applicant pool of 387 applicants (44% female, 54% male, 1% non-binary, and 1% no selection or prefer not to specify; 13% African American, 33% Asian, 15% Hispanic/Latino, 33% White, 4% Multiracial and 2% Others) from 44 states, Puerto Rico, and the UK. Thirty-four of these applicants were selected to participate in the REU program at NYIT. The program did not run in 2020 due to the pandemic. 62% of the REU fellows were from non-research institutions. 41% of the participants were female undergraduates in STEM majors. 35% of the participants are from underrepresented groups. Graduate assistants assisting the undergraduates with research include two female students and one minority student. With supplemental funding from NSF in 2021, four NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM) Scholars were also supported by the program.

NYIT REU Fellows produced 23 reports and 15 posters. They have published eight papers and two posters in peer-reviewed journals and conferences, which include IEEE Magnetics Letters, National Workshop for REU Research in Networking and Systems (REUNS) as part of the IEEE International Conference on Mobile Ad-Hoc and Smart Systems Conference (IEEE MASS) in 2019, 2021, 2022, 9th International Conference on Affective Computing and Intelligent Interaction (ACII) in 2021, IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing in 2022, and IEEE MIT Undergraduate Research Technology Conference (URTC) in 2021 and 2022. Two female REU fellows received travel grants for attending conferences and presenting their findings. Three of the NSF S-STEM scholars are co-authors of the two posters published.
